content.title: Dialysis Access Steal Syndrome (DASS)
content.description: Hand ischemia caused by diversion of arterial blood flow through a dialysis access, resulting in symptoms ranging from mild coldness to severe tissue loss.
content.definition: Dialysis access steal syndrome occurs when blood preferentially flows through the low-resistance fistula or graft rather than to the hand, causing distal ischemia. Severity ranges from mild (cool hand, numbness during dialysis) to severe (rest pain, tissue loss). More common with brachial artery access.

classification: Stage 1: Mild - cool hand, no pain, no intervention needed
Stage 2a: Moderate - pain only during dialysis
Stage 3: Severe - tissue loss, motor/sensory deficit
Ischemic monomelic neuropathy: Acute severe nerve ischemia
evaluation: Duplex ultrasound: Access flow, arterial disease
treatment_options: DRIL (Distal Revascularization Interval Ligation): Gold standard
RUDI (Revision Using Distal Inflow): Alternative to DRIL
Access ligation: If severe and salvage not possible

learning_objectives: Select appropriate treatment based on stage
clinical_pearls: All fistulas 'steal' flow - syndrome only when symptomatic
Ischemic monomelic neuropathy is a surgical emergency
DRIL preserves access while restoring distal perfusion
Stage 3 steal may require access ligation to save hand
Prevention: Consider radial access in high-risk patients
